text:
From the FFTW.jl's README.md:
> The FFTW library will be downloaded on versions of Julia where it is no longer distributed as part of Julia. Note that FFTW is licensed under GPLv2 or higher (see <http://www.fftw.org/doc/License-and-Copyright.html|its license file>), but the bindings to the library in this package, FFTW.jl, are licensed under MIT. This means that code using the FFTW library via the FFTW.jl bindings is subject to FFTW's licensing terms. Code using alternative implementations of the FFTW API, such as <https://software.intel.com/en-us/mkl-developer-reference-c-fftw3-interface-to-intel-math-kernel-library|MKL's FFTW3 interface> are instead subject to the alternative's license. If you distribute a derived or combined work, i.e. a program that links to and is distributed with the FFTW library, then that distribution falls under the terms of the GPL. If you just distribute source code that links to FFTW.jl, and users have to download FFTW or MKL to provide the backend, then the GPL probably doesn't have much effect on you.

text:
> Probably needs a copyright lawyer to sort this out. I've always thought that if your code directly calls GPL code, it has to be GPL. A colleague once said that GPL is like a virus.
That's not exactly it. A code base can have different files with different licenses, and as long as all of them are compatible you can distribute the whole code project under the most strict license. So for example, the whole project has to be GPL if some files are licensed under GPL, but other parts of the code can very well be MIT which is GPL compatible. And code bases that derive from the project as a whole or link to it would also be subject to GPL.

Still, you can look at the FFTW.jl code and use it to learn how to wrap a C library in julia and if you write another julia library based on your learning, then your code doesn't have to be GPL.

text:
> if you use it for hosting or help hosting a service that you sell, that counts too. 

No, it doesn't.

See AWS mongodb and elastic search drama.
The fact that AWS had no obligations at all was why those projects moved to the non-open source server side licence (SSL).
Though that goes far further than requiring your code to also be open source -- *AGPL* approximately does that.
SSL actually stops it being free to create and host a service.
(Because MongoDB and ElasticSearch are maintaines by SAAS companies of same name, and we're getting out compeated by AWS's offering)
